> In addition to importing Android Samples, the Code Sample Browser is a menu option inside Android Studio 2.2 Preview that allows you to find *high-quality, Google-provided* Android code samples based on the currently highlighted symbol in your project.
:joy:
Zomg
I browsed some of the samples for adapters. I saw 3 different code styles in 3 samples.
written by 3 interns
Official android code style guidelines is not to use hungarian notation
All javadoc for android uses hungarian notation
Consistency isn't exactly their strong point :stuck_out_tongue:
lot of android documentation is crap :grimacing:
Speaking of which, time to review javadoc on my current project :confused:

MVP TDD people - how does one mock (mockito) and test sharedpreferences? At the moment I have presenter which gets SharedPreferences injected to constructor and later I edit single preference.
To test that I thought simple mock(SharedPreferences.class) will be enough and just inject it to presenter, but I get nullpointer when I try editing preference. 
I guess mockito mocks only methods, not nester objects, but I'm not sure how should I go solving this?
Should I inject SharedPreference.Editor separately as well and use it for pref editing so I could mock it, or?..
Uuuh you inject android dependency into the presenter? Not a real good move
Wrap the preference fetcher in a pojo
Make it implement interface to which you set or inject the dependency source
<@U0548MM6B> Thanks

SAMMMSUUUNNNNGGGGGGGG!!!!!!!
Samsung Snackbar injected into coordinator layout doesn’t seem to be dismissable by swiping. Anyone got a clue?
<@U27LWJAJY|kazumeat> has joined the channel
Welp the guy that complained’s entire device is wonky, so it might be something else in this case. :’)

Another mocking question (Mockito) - how to mock Retrofit Call<>.enqueu()? Or in general how to mock nested stuff? In this case I'm mocking my service interface which obviously returns null Call class since its mocked. I could probably still get around it if it would be synchronous request and I would put it in tryCatch block and go as if nothing wrong happened, but problem comes with async request using a .enqueu(Callback)
look into retrofit-mock
<@U25NAS2P9>
`compile "com.squareup.retrofit2:retrofit-mock:${project.retrofitVersion}”;
Cheers <@U0QR1SM32>, was looking blindly into stackoverflow and missed this :smiley:
I probably should drink more/less coffee
Well I actually wrote some mocks earlier today :slightly_smiling_face:
<@U0QR1SM32|kristo> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/kristo/F27MQQE9G/-.java|Untitled>

file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight:
@Before
    public void setUp() throws Exception {
        Retrofit retrofit = new Retrofit.Builder()
                .addCallAdapterFactory(RxJavaCallAdapterFactory.create())
                .baseUrl("http://mock-response.com")

text: the `MockWebatlasApi` is just a POJO that implements my Api-interface
Damn I'm getting more and more excited as i get deeper into mvp and tdd
I am by no means an expert.. But getting more into it myself
Back in last year of university we were kind of thought TDD, but our project was using <http://ASP.NET|ASP.NET> MVC and we had absolutely no experience and no idea how to properly test/mock stuff
But now as I'm getting into android using mvp and tdd it's kind of fun
There is a school here in Oslo
they actually will not let studens pass without writing good tests
Oslo? Heh, I'm not far on oposite shore in Aalborg, Denmark
Which sounds.. awesome!
It's a little similar here, you won't pass or at least won't pass with good grades, but as long as you have like 20% coverage teachers will go 'eh, good enough'
A written test is nothing new for getting graduated :troll:
The fun part was that even when forced 80% of students still didn't get the purpose of tests :smiley:
:smile:
My school did not teach programming all that well.. I mean, there are so many things I wish I knew before going into my first job.
Like...? (secret 3rd year student here)
I mean besides obvious git, testing and stuff
You seem to be on the right track
I didn’t really know about MVP/MVC/MV* all that well, proper dependency injection, etc etc..
And what the benefits are

Oh dependency injection was a big buzz word for me until very recently :smile: Only like week ago started getting into Dagger and then found a talk where one sentence really explained basic idea - using constructors with arguments in them is basically dependency injection, all frameworks just take it a bit to next level by managing that better
The cool thing for me when all this “clicked” was how easy it was to learn NEW things

Random thought - how do those reminders to rate/support the app work? Are they time based? every X some UI trigger (e.g. button click) based?
Would've thought it'd be app dependant
mostly ui trigger as far as I can tell
I’ve seen examples where you count how many times something has happened (e.g screen launching)
launch the app,` if 5+ launches && user.hasRated == false { showPopup()}`
that
:stuck_out_tongue:
&& !user.hasRated you mean? :stuck_out_tongue:
I find that I tend to miss the `!` sometimes
== false reads better too
so I like to be explicit
or reads _easier_ atleast
I think easier at a glance
Yeh I guess it's harder to miss the condition that way
it’s hard to miss
I'm still deciding on that one
Sometimes I feel the one liner is nicer
consider this
`if (something) return;`
and many things will probably add more levels
I think the first case is way more explicit
also they stack well
Has anyone worked with HID compliant devices?
<@U08GFT5V5> Oh yeah I get that, I was talking about `if (something) return;` against the first case
Without braces
<@U1LJG0Y03> i have no opposition to that
perfectly valid
it looks cleaner but suffers the same problem as `!`
Might not see it
How do you guys test your apps in multiple devices? Emulator? Any specific tool? Actual devices?
What's testing? :stuck_out_tongue:
Seriously though, probably be best to ask in <#C0D6DUW8L|testing>

Is anyone semi-good at estimates? Friend asked on how much usually it takes to make usual semi-social app (login, profile, friends, likes, ads and purchases). Haven't done anything similiar so I have no idea what to say :smile:
if server side API is ready 40 day max..
<@U25NAS2P9> Split the app into features, split every feature in parts, split those parts again, estimate each part times 2 (or times 1.5 if you are good at estimations), add everything together
if you are in a team do some poker planning which is fun
i tried that before <@U09T8SFG8> its really fun and usually the guy who give less estimate on each task end up having most task to do on his list..
I loved poker planning in university, but I'm solo here :smiley:
Thanks for the tips tho
usually I'm really bad at estimating and underestimate stuff heavily
but <@U0XCFE6AH> in poker planning at least two people will be estimating a feature not one
<@U25NAS2P9> then everything you estimate make it times 2.5
don't estimate tests separately
in that case <@U25NAS2P9> divide the module into small task and then sort them in order like small, medium, large
they are part of the feature
<@U09T8SFG8> yeah that's what I heard that no matter how well you estimate you should multiply that by 3 :smile:
and assign hours to each like small -2 hour, medium 8 hour, large 2 days
depending on the skills sets
also <@U25NAS2P9> write the features as you would write user stories, it really helps to break things down
<@U25NAS2P9> i would say that really depends on how are you planning to work (review, qa, unit tests, ui tests, architecture) that increase your time exponentially

Hey, got a question about TDD, I just wrote a pretty lengthy test (50~ lines), which passes green lights, however the syntax and just some parts of the code can be shortened/encapsulated in classes/functions, do I need to keep refactoring the test until it seems good, or do I just do it in my production code ?
<@U18E0PY49> pretty subjective question
no good answer
just do what seems right for your situation
don't over-engineer in either tests or production :stuck_out_tongue:
if you're never going to update it again, just leave it alone
got it, thanks :smile:

I’ve tried overriding `saveState` in the adapter and not calling `super.onSaveInstanceState` but it always seems to save the state still

Other developer reports that he is getting “Installation blocked” dialog as well on Android issue tracker. <https://code.google.com/p/android/issues/detail?id=221585> Anti virus report says the apk has some problem in its zip file format. Google is taking a look on this issue...
